_source.description: We conduct a survey experiment testing the effects of different political rhetoric about the Covid-19 pandemic and the role of essential workers in the response on 1) public support for various policies affecting essential workers, and general attitudes toward those workers 2) the public’s views about their own responsibility for modifying their behavior in response to the pandemic, and 3) the status of the military relative to other occupations.
_source.title: Thank You For Your Service? Militaristic Rhetoric and Public Support for Covid-19 Essential Workers

_source.description: This project explores the causal effect of providing information to school boards on their deliberation and decision-making. The experimental portion of the project consists in measuring the causal effect of receiving a policy memo on school transportation in a COVID world. 300 school districts were treated, which means 2000 school board members and 1000 school administrators received the memo. The timeframe of the project (January 2020 - fall 2020) provides me with pre-and post- COVID data and allows me to follow 600 school boards as they go through an extraordinary year.
_source.title: Are school boards receptive to information: a field experiment

_source.description: Why do citizens support extrajudicial violence? _source.description: People construct a prototypical group member when evaluating their attitudes towards the group; however, this prototype cannot be raceless, agendered, or asexual; therefore, questions about attitudes towards one group rely on attitudes towards other groups not explicitly mentioned. This study will test the effects of implicit gendering and racing of a prototypical group member by adjusting the wording of questions in the racial resentment and modern sexism batteries to refer to different marginalized subgroups.
_source.title: Conditioning Attitudes: Intersecting Identities and Group Evaluations

_source.description: The impact of international laws is difficult to evaluate empirically. While previous studies argue that public support for international laws is considered vital for their self-enforcement, few studies have examined how international law changes public opinion. This research conducts a survey experiment in Japan in order to examine how information about violation of international law changes public opinion about domestic social and legal practices.
_source.title: The Impact of International Law on Public Opinion

_source.description: This analysis uses a Difference-in-Differences (DiD) design to assess how sectors' ethnic connections to the public sector (explanatory variable) influence levels of tariff liberalization (outcome variable) in Jordan. The DiD design compares tariff reductions from trade agreements signed just before and after the unexpected accession of Jordan's King Abdullah II in 1999.
_source.title: Ethnic Connections and Tariff Liberalization: Evidence from Royal Turnover in Jordan

_source.description: This is the Pre-Analysis Plan (PAP) of a proposed survey experiment designed to identify latent gender stereotypes for politicians in Brazil. This study is the first step of a more comprehensive research effort to understand how stereotypes affect the female participation in politics. A survey experiment will be used to estimate the differences in association of certain stereotypes with politicians by gender.
_source.title: Identifying gendered stereotypes for politicians in Brazil

_source.description: We propose a new method that not only measures sensitive attitudes, but also estimates the extent to which these attitudes can be swayed by an experimental intervention. Specifically, by combining list experiments with informational treatments, this project explores the heterogeneous treatment effect of different types of information on public attitudes towards imperial succession in Japan.
_source.title: Estimating Treatment Effects on Sensitive Attitudes: An Application to the Public Attitudes towards the Japanese Imperial Family

_source.description: Do female presidents’ (perceived) failures in office have consequences for voters’ biases towards female candidates, more generally? In this second study, we question the potential roles of gender salience and confirmation bias in explaining women’s and men’s reactions to Rousseff’s impeachment (uncovered in Study 1, pre-registered as 20180327AA).
_source.title: The Presidenta Effect: Perceptions of Women in Politics in Post-impeachment Brazil

_source.description: Test whether the effects of legalization policies on immigrants’ integration operate, in part, by communicating state and broader societal protection, more egalitarian treatment, and recognition of immigrants' contributions to their host country.
_source.title: Legalization Policies and the Integration of Immigrants

_source.description: Poll Wars: The effects of pre-election polls on voting behaviour
_source.title: Poll Wars: The effects of pre-election polls on voting behaviour

_source.description: The aim of this project is to gain a better understanding on which identities and group biases matter the most when it comes to the Covid-19 pandemic, and how this might be effected when individuals are prompted with different pieces of information pertaining to the underlying disparities of the pandemic. We expect that this experiment can help to better inform scholarly understanding of the situational importance of different identity categories, the responsiveness of individuals to various inequalities of the Covid-19 pandemic, and how both might affect respondents’ evaluations of political leaders and political opinion.
_source.title: 2020 Emotions, Covid and Politics Survey: The SARS-CoV-2, Race and Identity Experiment

_source.description: This study entails an experiment designed to examine why people resist compellent threats. Using a fictional foreign policy crisis vignette, we will compare how participants respond when they receive a direct compellent threat to how participants respond when they receive a `natural costs’ treatment that imposes the same costs without a threat. The study also aims to compare the effect of reactance to the effect of explicit reputation costs, and to examine reactance as a mechanism of compellence failure.
_source.title: The Psychology of Compellence Failure

_source.description: I explore how individuals perceive trade imbalances. I run survey experiments in China and the U.S. to test how positively citizens view trade deficits and surpluses with different countries.
_source.title: Mass public opinions towards trade balances: Mercantilism 2.0
Polarization, repression and authoritarian rule
Housing Quality and Individual Behavior in Slums during the COVID-19 Pandemic

_source.description: In this study, I explore primary elections as a venue for affective polarization-as-persuasion. While candidate appeals to negative partisanship in general elections can be a means for increasing turnout and participation among copartisans, what is the impact of candidate appeals to affective polarization in primary elections, with only one party on the ballot? The study uses a survey experiment to test voter support for candidates who use varying appeals to affective polarization.
_source.title: Out of Sight but in Mind: The Impact of Negative Partisanship in Congressional Primaries

_source.description: The study is a survey experiment collected over the phone to assess the extent to which voters support institutions meant to foster diversity in political representation. Specifically, we randomize information about the costs of inclusion of one group vis-à-vis another and ask a nationally-representative sample of Brazilian respondents about their level of agreement with quotas and the reservation of campaign finance for women, black, and LGBTQI+ candidates.
_source.title: More representation: Voters’ preferences and institutions for fostering diversity in representation

_source.description: The study is a survey experiment conducted in Europe, testing the causal effect of anti- and pro-immigrant contexts on immigrants' national belonging and political trust.
_source.title: Anti-Immigrant Contexts, Pro-Immigrant Support, and Immigrants' Subjective Integration

_source.description: This research looks at the relationship between social media information about violence, anxiety, and political beliefs. Using a conjoint experiment, I explore both whether citizens are more inclined to trust social media information, and if so why. Using an information experiment, I evaluate the relationship between knowledge and priors, social media information, anxiety, and political beliefs.
_source.title: The Democratization of Information? The Political Effects of Crowdsourcing Violence

_source.description: We use a randomized experiment across 120 communities in rural Liberia to evaluate the effects of interest-based negotiation (IBN) training on community leaders’ capacity to realize their conservation and/or development goals when making deals related to natural resources (e.g., forestland).
_source.title: Interest-based Negotiation over Natural Resources

_source.description: We conduct a survey experiment that studies the effects of social trust on compliance with state-level COVID-19 laws. News articles are used to manipulate stated levels of social trust. Lastly, we assess how partisanship, political trust, and social trust interact to impact compliance.
_source.title: The Effects of Social Trust on Compliance with COVID-19 Government Orders
Banklash: The Effects of Media Portrayals of Banks

_source.description: Even in a large protest where millions of population participate, most citizens remain as observers of the movement. When a protest takes a violent turn, either by the police force or by the protesters, many residents become direct or indirect observers, witnesses or sometimes victims of those violent incidents. This study aims to examine how citizens’ exposure to protest-related violence shifts their opinion about the government and the movement using survey experiments in Hong Kong. Anti-extradition bill protests in 2019 have created unprecedented political and social turmoil in Hong Kong, leading a large number of Hong Kong citizens to experience different levels of violence related to the current social movement. We examine how various forms of protest-related violence affect the public opinion of residents who experienced or observed the incidents, including trust in government, evaluation about the movement, and future prospects. In particular, we focus on different perpetrators of violence: violence by protesters, violence used by law enforcement, and violence by non-state counter-protest actors. The literature has shown that excessive repression against popular protest is politically costly and often ineffective in attenuating social grievances. Studies also generally confirm that violent protests lead to a decline in public support for the movement. Less well understood, however, is how citizens evaluate violent tactics used by different actors within the same movement and how individuals’ experiences with that violence may affect their political opinions. By identifying both treatment and control groups from the eight communities in the city that experienced a specific type of violent event last year, we aim to causally measure the public opinion changes related to protest-related violence at the micro-level.
_source.title: The Effects of Protest-related Violence on Neighborhoods

_source.description: Recent studies have challenged the traditional implicit/explicit model and found an increased tolerance for explicit racial appeals. This is happening as white identity is becoming more salient and relevant to American politics. This study explores whether implicit or explicit white identity appeals are rejected by political respondents and what effect these appeals have on attitudes towards race and immigration.
_source.title: White Identity Cues and the Explicit/Implicit Model

_source.description: This experiment examines whether and why parties decide to select (more) ethnic minority candidates (on eligible positions) as a response to other parties who have previously done so. Such knowledge will help to understand how the appearance of ethnic minority candidates changes over time.
_source.title: Do diffusion patterns explain the representation of ethnic minorities on candidate lists?

_source.title: Evaluating the Effectiveness of Singapore Government's Anti-Misinformation Strategies

_source.description: Questions remain regarding elements of our understanding of collective action and social movements. Van Zomeren, Postmes, & Spears (2008) ask the fundamental question: “What is it that mobilizes people to participate in social protest?” (p. 504). While the emphasis in this essay will be on a subjective predictor of collective action (sense of collective efficacy and the perception of the likelihood of group success), the practical question is whether activists, authority figures, and political leaders can inspire more or less participation in collective action, and to what extent, when framing the likelihood of collective action’s success in a positive or negative light.
_source.title: How Positive/Negative Framing Affects the Collective Action Social Dilemma

_source.description: We will test for differences in the trust in COVID-19 public health recommendations and intention to follow recommendations across 5 different public institutions.
_source.title: Partisan Differences in Public Trust Across Institutions: Does the Message Matter?

_source.description: An experiment that examines how presidential candidates’ foreign policy positions shape voters’ assessments of their personal attributes.
_source.title: Commander-in-Chief Test, Chapter 3

_source.description: This research handles the intersection of governance and livelihoods vulnerability in the context of the COVID-19 pandemic in three districts of Masvingo Province, Zimbabwe. The study looks at the pandemic induced reconfigurations in income and expenditure variances, savings and food consumption among household that depends on informal economy.
_source.title: Informal economy, vulnerability and marginalization in times of pandemic: Evidence from Masvingo Province, Zimbabwe

_source.description: At the time of the survey there are three COVID vaccines approved for use in the United States, with varying degrees of efficacy, convenience, and safety levels (side effects). It is unknown whether the public will have preferences for one of the vaccines over the other, but there are concerns that one vaccine may be viewed as inferior to the others. If there are differences in acceptance of one or another vaccine among subgroups of the population, officials should tailor the distribution of the vaccines to groups with higher acceptance of each type, all else equal.
_source.title: COVID vaccine choice: Preferences for and acceptance of the first three COVID vaccines in the United States

_source.description: In this study, we examine whether there are gender/class differences in the performance of participants depending on whether they are informed beforehand that their performance score and demographic characteristics will be known to an evaluator who will compare them to the scores and characteristics of others, and use this information to decide which participant is better.
_source.title: Performance under evaluation: the cases of social class and gender

_source.description: A large area of propaganda research is the top-down effects of propaganda. Existing studies have yielded mixed results regarding the effects of authoritarian propaganda. Despite the enormous efforts we have put in exploring the effectiveness of propaganda, there are still some aspects we overlooked. Probably due to the lack of direct empirical evidence our community has on bottom-up psychological needs for propaganda, we do not have much knowledge how propaganda effects vary across individuals with distinct psychological predispositions yet. And as people desire for propaganda out of various psychological motivations, we would imagine, for example, propaganda effects would be different for individuals who desire it out of utilitarian needs versus individuals who welcome propaganda out of ego-defensive psychological motivations. This study aims to examine the heterogenous propaganda effect across individuals, situations, and propaganda types.
_source.title: The Heterogeneous Downstream Effects of Propaganda
Benchmarking and norm change
Dispute Resolution in Sub-Saharan Africa: What Drives Turning to State Versus Non-State Authorities

_source.description: Does an origin of income shock matter for citizen support for government compensation? Existing literature provides mixed predictions. Some argue that economic hardship, regardless of its origin, increases public support for a larger government and other left-leaning values (Wright 2008; Margalit 2011), while others argue that different origins of income shock are associated with a right vs. left-leaning public through blame assignment by voters and their beliefs about the recipients’ “deservedness” (Autor et al. 2013; Guisinger 2017; Naoi 2020 a, b, c; Tella and Rodrik 2020). To answer this question, we design and field a survey experiment with the Cooperative Congressional Election Studies (CCES), the nationally representative sample of U.S. respondents that manipulate information regarding the sources of an American worker’s income losses spanning four sources: trade policy; pandemic; shelter-in-place order; or unspecified cause.
_source.title: Do Trade vs. Pandemic-originated Income Shocks Mobilize Higher Support for Government Compensation? Experiment Evidence from the United States

_source.description: We will field a vignette study to understand whether political trust effects redistribution preferences. The vignettes are designed to influence trust and then we use this experimentally-induced variation to study downstream effects on various aspects of redistribution.
_source.title: Does Political Trust Influence Redistribution Preferences? Evidence from a Vignette Experiment

_source.description: This study explores how policy design affects public support for international cooperation between the European Union and non-EU countries on migration management. In particular, it assesses which features of international cooperation are more likely to generate public support or opposition.
_source.title: Policy design and public preferences for international cooperation in the area of migration management: evidence from cross-national conjoint experiments

_source.description: This research has two main goals. First, it will test existing arguments using group level characteristics. Second, it complements the literature by highlighting the importance of security concerns and how they shape attitudes in developing countries that experience civil conflict, which host the most of refugees. In order to test its arguments, a conjoint experiment in Turkey will be carried out.
_source.title: Security Concerns and Attitudes toward Refugees

_source.description: This study examines US public support for varying cybersecurity responses to cyberthreats from a foreign power (Russia). The study examines whether publics prefer escalatory, proportional, or de-escalatory responses to cyberattacks. The study also considers whether awareness of cyberattacks and cyber responses increase feelings of vulnerability with respect to individual and collective cyber targets.
_source.title: Cyber Threat and Cyber Security in the United States

_source.description: We conduct a survey experiment that studies the effects of political trust and partisan communication on compliance with state-level COVID-19 laws. Newspaper articles are used as treatments for the political trust part of the experiment; we study the effect of partisan communication by prompting governors of different parties that implemented COVID-19 mitigation orders. Lastly, we assess how partisan communication and political trust interact.
_source.title: The Effects of Political Trust and Partisan Communication on Compliance with COVID-19 Government Orders

_source.description: We test a battery of heterogeneous behavioral effects on different ‘at-risk’ subpopulations in a realistic simulated news feed. Additionally, we test whether simply priming the existence of deepfakes – through benign information interventions or chance recognition ‘in the wild’ – reduces trust in media. Finally, we provide the first descriptive evidence of the ability of a well-informed population to distinguish deepfake videos from sincere videos.
_source.title: An Experiment on the Effect of Political Deepfakes on Beliefs and Attitudes

_source.description: This project will explore the role of voters’ values in evaluating candidates accused of sexual misconduct. We ask two research questions: (1) Are candidates punished for allegations of sexual misconduct? (2) Do values play a role when evaluating candidates linked to allegations of sexual misconduct?
_source.title: Candidate evaluation and sex scandal: A survey experiment

_source.description: In Europe today, there is still a large gap in political participation between immigrants and native citizens. For example, although mobile EU citizens (EU citizens residing outside their home country) have the right to vote in local elections in their country of residence, they often do not participate in these elections. These gaps in participation matter, as they can exacerbate existing political inequalities. This research project explores if social media interventions (Facebook groups and pages) are effective in increasing the political participation of immigrants. The project tests this through a field experiment with local civil society partner organisations, taking place in the run up to local elections in one federal state in Germany.
_source.title: Mobilising migrants: how effective are online interventions in increasing political participation among immigrants?

_source.description: We examine how power transitions affect public support for international economic cooperation in the U.S. and the People’s Republic of China. We run survey experiments in both countries to test whether citizens from the declining country are more critical of cooperation whereas citizens in the rising country are keen to foster global cooperation.
_source.title: Power Transitions and International Economic Cooperation: Experimental Evidence from China and the U.S.

_source.description: The study conducts a conjoint survey experiment to identify how patterns of violence shape individual decisions to flee. We explore if and how individuals that are more open to change make different forced migration decisions than individuals with less openness to risk.
_source.title: Behavioral Aspects of Forced Migration Decisions – A conjoint experiment in Eastern and Southeastern Turkey

_source.description: Immigration courts’ growing reliance on video teleconferencing (VTC) technology in immigration proceedings raises concerns about procedural fairness. However, a body of work in judicial politics suggests when citizens are exposed to the symbols of law, their latent positive attitudes towards courts are awakened, making them more accepting of otherwise unfavorable judicial outcomes. This study leverages a 2x3 fully crossed factorial survey experiment to evaluate the effects of VTC use and technology malfunctions, both with and absent the legitimizing symbols of the judiciary, on perceptions of procedural fairness, legitimacy, and outcome acceptance. Ultimately, I build on the literature on expectation and satisfaction to model the interaction between legal symbols and VTC courtrooms as one in which expectations and reality are misaligned and disconfirmation bias emerges, lowering public opinion.
_source.title: Virtual Legality: ‘’Asylum Free Zones,” Video Teleconferencing, and Bad Tech in U.S. Immigration Courts

_source.description: Two conjoint experiments that examine how voters determine the extent to which presidential candidates are fit to be commander-in-chief.

_source.title: Can Religion Increase Compliance with COVID-19 Prevention Measures?

_source.description: This document describes the design and planned analysis of a randomized field experiment aimed at registering currently unregistered citizens to vote in the 2020 presidential election in Wisconsin. A central challenge for voter registration is the absence of a list of citizens who are not currently registered to vote. Unlike get-out-the-vote campaigns, which typically start from a list of registered voters as compiled on the voter file, registration campaigns have to identify unregistered voters by other means. We also do not have a list of unregistered voters, but we proxy for this list with the maps of unregistered households produced and shared by mapthevote.com. In treatment neighborhoods (census block groups), we will email all currently registered voters a map of the nearby unregistered households and encourage them to register their neighbors. Our study draws on insights from the nascent literature on relational organizing, which finds that inducements from close social contacts have especially large effects on voter turnout \citep{green2020_supertreatment}. In our study, we hope to cause currently registered voters to induce their currently unregistered neighbors to vote. This form of organizing is ``relational'' in the sense that it relies on the unmeasured but nevertheless real social network of neighbors in neighborhoods. Our operating assumption is that even though most neighbors don't know most neighbors personally, all neighbors are known to at least some neighbors.
_source.title: Relational Registration Field Experiment

_source.description: In emerging markets, where much of the world’s future demand for energy and infrastructure will be located, there is a clear recognition of the central role that businesses can play in promoting green growth and climate action. However, there is less clarity about how to motivate private firms to invest in green technologies and environmentally operations. Some scholars and practitioners emphasize enhanced government regulation and enforcement, while others point to the greater potential of societal pressure. In this study, we plan to use a survey experiment embedded in nationally representative surveys in Vietnam and Myanmar to test which type of stakeholder pressure (government or society) has the strongest impact on whether and how much domestic and foreign business leaders are willing to invest in green operations. In addition, we plan to test how important firm characteristics, such as firm size, export market, ownership structure, and firms’ environmental risk perception moderate this relationship. Below, we present our pre-analysis plan and mock results for this proposed study.
_source.title: What Drives Corporate Environmentalism in Developing Countries?
Democracy Ratings, Part 2

_source.description: This study uses a difference-in-differences design to explore the impact of wildfires on voting behaviour in Australia. Specifically, it seeks to assess the extent to which exposure to wildfires affects support for both green parties and anti-immigrant parties. Its focus is on regional election outcomes from Queensland, a region that was heavily exposed to wildfires during 2019-20.
_source.title: Green Shoots from the Ashes? The Impact of Australian Wildfires on Voting Behaviour

_source.description: Who Did What to Whom: A Survey Experiment on Public Attitudes Toward Abusing Human Rights
_source.title: Who Did What to Whom: A Survey Experiment on Public Attitudes Toward Abusing Human Rights
The Impact of Public Diplomacy on the Global Attitudes of Teens

_source.description: This study uses a survey-experimental method to investigate the tendency for voters, particularly female voters, to continue to support politicians who make sexist remarks. Previous studies have found that sexist attitudes correlate with such support. In this study, we propose another explanation: social conformity. A longstanding theory in social phycology suggests that people change their opinions to match others’ responses (Asch 1951). We explore the effects of social conformity using the case of President Duterte of the Philippines, who repeatedly made sexist remarks. We show participants a video clip of Duterte’s sexist remark that he made during his 2016 presidential campaign. Our treatment condition is a version of the video that includes audience laughter, which we regard as a proxy for social influence that imparts social conformity pressure. Our control condition is a version of the video without laughter.
_source.title: Social Influence on Voter Support of Sexist Politicians: A Survey Experiment from the Philippines

_source.description: We execute a series of survey experiments that randomly vary whether the survey measures turnout intentions (a) in the standard way, independently of candidate preferences (the control condition), or (b) as part of the candidate preference question, with "not vote" appearing one of the response options (the treatment condition). We compare both groups’ stated vote intentions to their validated vote behavior. We hypothesize that the treatment strengthens the relationship between perceptions of differences between parties/candidates and the intention to turnout, particularly among those with high levels of group consciousness, such as African Americans. As such, we predict that it reduces stated intentions to vote overall, thereby mitigating the degree to which pre-election surveys tend to overestimate turnout.
_source.title: Reviving the “B-Term” in Estimates of the Calculus of Voting

_source.description: The study is a survey experiment collected online to assess the dynamics of vote- buying and the representation of marginalised groups in Brazil, during an election taking place during a global pandemic. To do this, we expose participants to vignettes that describe candidates’ campaign activities during the current municipal elections in Brazil and randomise the types of campaign activities carried out and the gender of candidates, so that each participant is only exposed to one combination. We will test the effects of a candidates’ gender and type of campaign tactics in mediating voters’ evaluations of candidates’ levels of electability, proneness to vote buying, and voter responsiveness.
_source.title: Elections during a pandemic: the effects of Covid-19 on the representation of women, voter turnout, and trust in politicians
Who Stays? The Role of Nationalism and Dignity in Decisions to Stay in Conflict and other Refugee-Causing Situations

_source.description: Brief description of study – This study attempts to understand and measure the relationship between issue complexity, motivated self-interest, and rhetorical credibility in international legal domains. It is comprised of a formally-motivated randomized controlled trial that relies on a text-based simulation environment. Lawyers and law students are sampled.
_source.title: Issue Complexity and Downstream Compliance
Hiding From the Heat: Why Tucson Failed to Become a Sanctuary City
Shared Disadvantage, Shared Identity? Explaining When and Why White Americans Support Non-Merit Based Admissions Policies
The Paradoxical Effects of Combating Corruption on Institutional Trust and Political Engagement

_source.description: The study combines observational data on political statements with a survey experiment. The goal of the study is to understand the political impact of linking natural disasters to climate change.
_source.title: Natural Disasters and the Tradeoffs of Climate Change Attribution

_source.description: This study examines the role of women during independence movements and the post-war effects on women as countries move towards a democratic state. It seeks to answer to the question of why newly-independent states tend to revert to gender inequitable politics and societal norms despite the promise for equality. This study will be conducting through interviews with women activists and leaders in Algeria and Palestine as well as data analysis from available datasets and newspaper articles.
_source.title: Women’s Resistance in Independence Movements in the Middle East and Northern Africa

_source.description: This study attempts to examine the effects of media manipulation under authoritarianism on attitudes and the mechanism through which it works. Specifically, it examined the effect of one type of media manipulation—manipulation rhetoric of security threats and conspiracies. It does so using a survey experiment in Egypt.
_source.title: The effects of autocratic media on attitudes

_source.description: We examine whether populism makes individuals more likely to endorse false claims and reject corrections. We do so with survey experiments in Spain and Portugal --- countries with similar socioeconomic and cultural characteristics but different levels of elite and mass populism.
_source.title: Populism and the persistence of misinformation: Experimental evidence from Europe

_source.description: The study investigates the use of cognitive schemas as a means of overcoming ambiguity inherent in cyberspace. Schemas function as a source of strategic preferences in cyberspace. However, schema-consistent preferences may not align with the realities faced in cyberspace, resulting in sub-optimal results.
_source.title: Strategic Preferences in Cyberspace: A Schematic Approach

_source.description: Through an online survey experiment that varies exposure to different languages, this project studies the consequences of bilingualism on political preferences. Specifically, it studies how bilingualism in the dominant or majority language of a multilingual nation-state affects individuals of ethnicities associated with minority languages.
_source.title: Bilingualism and Political Attitudes in South India

_source.description: A design for soliciting, selecting, and aggregating community-provided socio-political models predicting Covid-19 mortality.
_source.title: Crowdsourcing Political Models of Covid-19 Mortality

_source.description: The experiment is conducted at the end of a second wave survey of UK (GB ex NI) adults conducted with YouGov. We anticipate around 1165 respondents. After answering the bulk of the survey respondents will be randomized with equal probability into receiving one of three question wordings. Each question wording emphasises a different aspect of Britain’s COVID-19 vaccination program and asks how willing the respondent would be to take an approved vaccine. Following this question, respondents will see one more question, which asks them their approval for four government vaccine policies.
_source.title: Coping with Covid: Second Wave Survey Experiment

_source.description: Can initiatives led by a sport’s team shape its members’ socio-political attitudes? To answer this question, current study will conduct a survey experiment with fans of the Esporte Clube Bahia (Bahia Football Club)—deemed by The Guardian Brazil’s ‘most progressive football team’. In particular, the survey design will allow us to examine whether the Club’s anti-racism and anti-sexism initiatives can impact fans attitudes towards race and gender equalities.
_source.title: They strike again: The impacts of a football club’s progressive initiatives on the attitudes of their fans

_source.description: In this project, we propose to conduct analyses of elections and well-being in Uganda. Elections, we believe, will produce both positive and negative effect on wellbeing, but the latter will dominate since there is a history of serious problems associated with elections there which have become especially pronounced recently.
_source.title: Elections and Well-Being in Africa: An Experimental Analysis of Uganda

_source.description: We examine whether European voters update their views about the EU when exposed to information about EU actions, in the form of cooperation with non-EU countries, to tackle irregular migration.
_source.title: EU cooperation with third countries on migration management and its effects on public opinion about the EU

_source.description: How does exposure to exogenous shocks alter women’s political preferences and behavior, and norms around women’s participation in politics? The goal of this study is to understand the differential impact of two different types of shocks, climate change-induced disasters and Covid-19 in Bangladesh.
_source.title: COVID-19 & Climate Shocks: Gendered effects on political preferences & behavior

_source.description: n/a
_source.title: Weak Rule of Law and Perceived Legitimacy

_source.description: Censorship in China is massive in scale and still growing. Previous studies of censorship in China focus primarily on government criticism and collective actions and find that political censorship will lead to backlash from the citizens. However, novel observational evidence shows that a majority of censored articles are unrelated to either government criticism or collective actions. This study investigates the implication of such expansion in range and scale of censorship. It hypothesizes that when censorship is expanded beyond government criticism and collective action, backlash from the citizens will be reduced.
_source.title: Normalization of Censorship: Evidence from China

_source.description: The purpose of this study is to examine Americans’ support for co-partisan candidates who make undemocratic statements, and whether this support is susceptible to political messages from co-partisan elites. The study takes the form of an experiment embedded in a survey, in which subjects will be randomly assigned to a message which either approves or disapproves of a hypothetical candidate based on their statements. The survey conducted will a be pilot survey using the MTurk platform delivered through Qualtrics, during which the focus will be on whether the experimental treatments show any evidence of effectiveness in changing individuals’ willingness to support a candidate who has made undemocratic statements.
_source.title: Partisanship, Democratic Norms & Candidate Support

_source.description: This study uses a behavioral game and survey vignette questions to test the argument that micro-level backlash against women is especially likely to occur in contexts where equal rights for women are supported, but where the perceived norm remains that women are or ought to be more communal and oriented toward social cohesion than men (high expectations backlash). It also assesses three alternative hypotheses: (1) punitive behavior toward women might result from any perceived violation or transgression of women’s position and “natural” roles, regardless of whether equal rights are supported in principle (hostile backlash), (2) reminding individuals of benevolent sexist beliefs may lead them to treat women more leniently than men out of a protective impulse (benevolent lenience), and (3) support for equal rights may be enough to induce equal treatment of men and women (egalitarian fairness).
_source.title: Women’s Rights and Ambivalent Sexism: Backlash or Benevolence?

_source.description: We test for whether susceptibility to save/loss frames differs in the United States in the classic disease outbreak scenario by randomly changing information about the disease origin. Under dual process theory, individuals have two modes of decision-making, a slow, methodical, rational mode and a quick process that relies on heuristics and can result in cognitive biases. Heightened emotions can trigger individuals to move from the first to the second state. We hypothesize that the greater degree of unfamiliarity will induce fear and increase the susceptibility to framing bias.
_source.title: Susceptibility to Framing Bias: Does “Othering” Induce More Switching from Risk To Loss Aversion Under Save &/Loss Frames?

_source.description: Drawing on the case of Colombia, this study aims at identifying the effect of misinformation on the intention to get vaccinated against Covid-19. We propose a survey experiment where we divide respondents into four groups: one is exposed to misinformation related to the alleged uncertainty around Covid-19 vaccines; a second group is exposed to information refuting the misinformation explicitly mentioning it (priming); the third group is exposed to information refuting that false narrative but avoiding to mentioning it (not priming); and the fourth group is exposed to information not related to vaccines nor Covid (control group/placebo). By recognizing how Covid-19 immunization discourses influence citizens’ intentions to get vaccinated, our results shed light on future challenges to immunization plans in the Global South.
_source.title: “When will the Vaccine Arrive?” The effect of misinformation on Colombians’ intentions to get a vaccine to prevent Covid-19

_source.description: The current COVID-19 pandemic has undoubtedly had a significant adverse effect on world democracies, especially elections scheduled in the year, 2020. We investigate how the COVID-19 pandemic affected the administration, participation, and outcome of elections. In particular, the study focuses on perceptions, behaviours, and preferences of voters towards Ghana’s 2020 elections in the midst of COVID-19 pandemic; as well as the extent to which COVID-19 affected voter registration and election turnout rates.
_source.title: COVID-19 and Elections: The Case of 2020 General Elections in Ghana

_source.description: In this project, we ask how to reduce exclusionary attitudes towards immigrants in developing countries. We implement a perspective-getting intervention that could potentially reduce exclusionary attitudes towards Venezuelan immigrants in Colombia.
_source.title: Survey Experiment on the Reduction of Prejudice against Migrants

_source.description: This study aims to disentangle the effect of statistical discrimination and status mechanisms on discrimination in the cases of social class and gender. It does so by varying the level of information on performance of task-players seen by a sample of task-evaluators.
_source.title: Social class and gender discrimination – testing status and statistical discrimination mechanisms

_source.description: Names, Faces, Accents, and Jobs: Disaggregating Components of Perceived Race and Ethnicity
_source.title: Names, Faces, Accents, and Jobs: Disaggregating Components of Perceived Race and Ethnicity

_source.description: This study evaluates the effects of source of information on compliance of public health measures in response to Covid -19 in Kibera, an informal settlement in Nairobi. The study varies the source of information with the content of the message being similar across the three treatment groups. Participants’ are sent audio recordings from their village elder, local celebrity or a nurse from a government hospital depending on their treatment group. This study is being conducted remotely through phone surveys with a sample of 349 participants
_source.title: Effect of source of information on compliance of public health measures in response to Covid -19

_source.description: Analyse the effect of violence on political participation, particularly whether there is a difference between men and women in the effect of exposure to violence on expressed interest in political and political participation.
_source.title: Gender, violence and political participation

_source.description: Female Protectionism: Women’s Responses to Gendered Labor Markets
_source.title: Female Protectionism: Women’s Responses to Gendered Labor Markets

_source.description: We examine voters’ assessment of the U.S.- Chinese trade negotiations through the lens of an international bargaining model (Fearon 1995). We run survey experiments in both countries to test how voters subjectively assess the key parameters of the theoretical model that matter for the negotiations and their outcome.
_source.title: The Mass Politics of Trade Wars: Asymmetric Perceptions, Electoral Motives and U.S.-Chinese Bargaining

_source.description: I explore how easy it is to shift cooperation attitudes with reliable or unreliable past behaviour. I run survey experiments in China and the U.S. to test whether and how citizens change their preference for cooperation with allies and adversaries when confronted with unreliable or reliable past behaviour in trade policy.
_source.title: The Vulnerability of Alliance Reputation: How Unreliability Wrecks Bilateral Trade Cooperation

_source.description: The study tests voter attitudes towards women in Indian politics and reservation for women in politics. It also gauges voter preferences between ideal candidates through a paired conjoint analysis.
_source.title: Voter attitudes towards female political participation in India

_source.description: With a focus on Japan, we replicate a study recently published in the flagship journal of political science (Allen, M. A., Flynn, M. E., MacHain, C. M., & Stravers, A. 2020. “Outside the Wire: U.S. Military Deployments and Public Opinion in Host States.” American Political Science Review, Volume 114, Issue 2, pages 326–341). Specifically, we examine how attitudes toward the U.S. military presence in Japan are different between people in Okinawa, a very small prefecture hosting the bulk of the U.S. military facilities in Japan, and people in other prefectures. Also, based on a conjoint experiment, we investigate Japanese citizens’ Not-in-my-back-yard (NIMBY) attitudes toward the military facilities within Japan.
_source.title: Japanese Attitudes toward the U.S. Military Presence: Do Okinawans Have Distinct Preferences?

_source.description: The project aims to better understand how conflict affects in-group and out-group cooperation and prosociality by tracking individuals living in the epicenter of the Kamuina Nsapu insurgency, which occurred in 2017 in the Democratic Republic of the Congo. We have collected a rich set of pre-conflict measures of in-group and out-group cooperation and pro-sociality. We will collect these same measures now that the conflict is over. Thus, we will be able to examine individual-level changes in these traits before and after the rebellion and compare these changes to the extent to which individuals were affected by the conflict.
_source.title: The Dynamic Effects of Conflict on Prosociality: Evidence from the Kamuina Nsapu Insurgency

_source.description: This study empirically examines the impact of perceived consequences of the COVID-19 pandemic on the foreign policy preferences of the Chinese public. We field two original surveys in China during the height of the pandemic to assess the relationship between beliefs about the geo-political implications of COVID-19 and Chinese public support for use of military force.
_source.title: Foreign Policy Revisionism in the Era of COVID-19: Theory and Evidence from Chinese Public Opinion

_source.description: Public support for international laws and treaties is considered vital for their self-enforcement. However, existing studies often conflate how voters weigh the legal (possible penalties) and normative (possible ostracism) costs of violating international agreements. Our research examines how different types of information about international laws versus norms influence public opinion about domestic rules and social conventions that run counter to global standards.
_source.title: The Impact of International Laws vs. Norms on Public Opinion

_source.description: This study uses the survey-experiment methodology to test hypotheses from Terror Management Theory, with some innovations, in the Brazilian context. The study tries to assess the effect of two different primings and their combination (the subjects of “death” and “the historical brevity of Brazil as and independent country”) on the subject’s desire to leave a legacy after death and to achieve some form of immortality (experiment 1) and on the support for religious intolerance and xenophobia (experiment 2).
_source.title: Kingdom Not of This World: The role of death thoughts in xenophobia and religious intolerance

_source.description: This study explores public attitudes towards international actors in the context of Italy’s struggle to contain the coronavirus emergency in the spring of 2020. Concretely, we test whether information cues about acts of “public diplomacy” by different international actors (China, the United States and the EU) shape peoples’ attitudes towards these actors.
_source.title: Shifting Public Attitudes towards International Actors in Times of Emergency Evidence from Italy

_source.description: I am conducting two complementary conjoint experiments with the government and Chinese companies in Nigeria where both parties are presented with hypothetical investment deals that they are asked to rate. The experiments allow us for the first time to measure how technical advisors to the Nigerian federal government and Lagos state government assesses their bargaining power with investors, how Chinese companies in Nigeria assess their bargaining power with the Nigerian government, and finally how the government and the companies consequently act or do not act on their bargaining power.
_source.title: African Bargaining Power & Chinese Investment Deals

_source.description: We evaluate a correction strategy to reduce COVID-19 misinformation in India through an online experiment (N=1500). We present respondents with corrections from unlikely sources and evaluate the effect of these treatments on perceived accuracy of COVID-19 miracle cures and conspiracy theory headlines.
_source.title: Conspiracy Theories and Miracle Cures: Fighting COVID-19 Misinformation in India

_source.description: This study examines the role of emotion, in particular anger and anxiety, in driving support for populist candidates and policies in the United States. Using two survey experiments, I will first measure whether or not populist messaging--in the form of artificial populist campaign ads--are capable of causing changes in emotional state among respondents. In the second study, I will measure whether changes in emotional state cause individuals to display higher levels of support for populism, nativism, and authoritarianism through the use of behavioral scales.
_source.title: Angry Politics: The Role of Emotion and Identity in Driving Populist Attitudes and Behavior in the United States

_source.description: The objective of this study is to investigate how and to what extent women’s income earning abilities, women’s decision-making power with regard to food purchases and use of income, women’s diet diversity, the relation between women’s income earning abilities and their decision-making power, and the relation between women’s decision-making power and their diet diversity changed over the course of the last 12 months, during with the Covid-19 pandemic occurred and several measures were implemented to reduce its spread and impact.
_source.title: Covid-19-related changes in the relation between women’s empowerment in the household and women’s diet diversity in southern Bangladesh

_source.description: Survey Experiment on the Italian 2020 Referendum Campaign
_source.title: Survey Experiment on the Italian 2020 Referendum Campaign

_source.description: This study includes two survey experiments designed to investigate how structural transformations of the economy and society affect identities that underlie a second ‘universalism- particularism’ dimension of politics. These two survey experiments focus respectively on whether 1) increasing inequality between educational groups and 2) increasing inequality between spatially defined groups might exacerbate identity-based political divides.
_source.title: Social Identities in the Politics of the Knowledge Society – How Education and Geography Structure Perceptions of ‘Us’ and ‘Them’

_source.description: This survey experiment tests two messaging strategies on voter willingness to support bond measures for water utility risk mitigation programs. It also seeks to measure how experience with other on-going hazards, such as wildfires and the Covid-19 pandemic, influence support for these bond measures.
_source.title: Voter Willingness to Address “Public Bads”: How to Alter Citizen Perceptions of the Risks Posed by Natural and Manmade Hazards
Reacting to the Olive Branch: Hawks, Doves, and Public Support for Cooperation
How do informational outreach campaigns impact immigrants’ naturalization decisions? Evidence from a randomized control trial in Switzerland

_source.description: This project tests and compares the effect of praising and of shaming on individuals’ support for international agreements. Specifically, it tests whether praising or shaming leads individuals to support their country joining a hypothetical international agreement that would ban the use of explosive weapons.
_source.title: Praising Versus Shaming in Support for International Agreements

_source.description: This project addresses the question of how citizens evaluate the decisions of their representatives to reallocate revenues for public works projects. We present survey respondents with a short vignette about a city road project in which we experimentally manipulate the distribution of benefits in the city, as well as to the district of the respondent. We then as respondents to evaluate their representative, as well as the project.
_source.title: Citizens’ Preferences for Distributive Outcomes

_source.description: This paper asks: What are the underpinnings of elevated xenophobia in Colombia toward Venezuelans? Drawing on the literature of International Political Economy and Comparative Politics, this article explores the factors explaining xenophobia among the Colombian population.
_source.title: Brother or Stranger?: Causes of Xenophobia in Colombia

_source.description: Why do citizens vote for candidates associated with drug-trafficking? Due to the nature of drug-trafficking – which brings larger profits, higher risk of violence, and impacts in social orders – this study evaluates whether the trade-off of corruption hypothesis applies to this different type of illegal behavior.
_source.title: Electoral Support for Candidates Involved in Drug-Trafficking: Experimental Evidence from Peru
The Reception of Venezuelan Migrants in Colombia
Rewarding Women’s Rights in Dictatorships

_source.description: Apartments “Destroy the Suburbs?”: The Racialization and Nationalization of Zoning
_source.title: Apartments “Destroy the Suburbs?”: The Racialization and Nationalization of Zoning

_source.description: Studies of lobbying strategies have suggested that indirect lobbying strategies are more likely to be favored for issues that can be framed as having a potentially broad and interested audience. However, in reality, interest groups attempt to influence voters' perceptions even when voters are not interested or have a flat prior. In this paper, I dive into the dynamics of indirect political influence on voters' perception of free trade, which is relatively less salient in US politics compared to other issues.
_source.title: Indirect Competition for Political Influence

_source.description: This project investigates how the availability of private alternatives to publicly provided benefits changes voters' support for the welfare state. We focus on the growing availability of credit. The notion that n credit markets and welfare states rests on the assumptions of voters' consent, either explicitly through electoral behavior or implicitly through weakened demand for more public spending. Through a set of survey experiments, we study if the introduction and availability of credit in addition to publicly provided goods and services influence voters’ support for government spending in the domains of social insurance, education, childcare, and housing.
_source.title: How Credit Markets Shape Beliefs About a Just Redistributive System

_source.description: When learning about judicial candidates running for re-election, this study looks at whether off-the-bench articles, such as stories about the justice’s lives outside of the Court, or on-the-bench articles, such as stories about the justices participating in Court activities, motivate justices to learn more about the Court. I look at voters from three states with justices running for re-election: Missouri, Michigan, and New Mexico in the upcoming November 2020 general election.
_source.title: Interest in Judicial Candidates
Authority and Legitimacy: Evidence from Cross-National Conjoint Endorsement Experiments
The Marginalization of Migrants: Examining the Differential Effects of Identity and Socio-Economic Status on the Acceptance of Migrants
The Contingency of Clientelism: Vote Buying and Voting Calculus

_source.description: In this study, we use a conjoint survey experiment to examine how the ethnic identities and campaign platforms of women candidates influence their electability in India’s state-level elections, with a focus on the state of Bihar. We also examine how exposure to ethnic violence and experiences with gender discrimination and empowerment shape the attitudes of voters to women candidates.
_source.title: Electing Women in Ethnically Divided Societies
How Do Religious Appeals Shape Intergroup Tolerance and Radicalization? Evidence from Burkina Faso

_source.description: Democratic stability depends on popular acceptance of the institutional checks and balances of the state, particularly the structures of the executive, legislature, and central-local governance. However, preferences over individual institutions may be influenced by how the consequences of those choices are framed, and by preceding or preexisting choices with regard to other institutions. This research conducts a survey experiment in Japan in order to examine how choices over majoritarian versus consensual institutions are conditional on 1) the background information provided, and 2) the order in which discrete institutions are selected.
_source.title: Preferences for Majoritarian vs. Consensual Institutions

_source.description: This study conducts a general survey to examine the distribution of Chinese citizens’ various psychological needs. Through calculating respondents’ scores on five psychology test scales, this study will show what psychological needs are more salient to Chinese citizens.
_source.title: The Distribution of Chinese Citizens’ Psychological Needs

_source.description: This study examines the relationship between affective polarization, and social activism in the United States with an emphasis on LGBT and racial justice movements. The study includes behavioral experiments (dictator games) to measure affective polarization across political party lines and survey experiments with varying treatments related to LGBT and Black Lives Matter activism and their intersections or lack thereof. Several survey experiments also examine the power of recent Supreme Court rulings on attitudes toward LGBT rights specifically.
_source.title: Social Activism and Affective Polarization in the United States

_source.description: American Indian Authorities, Trust, and Collective Action during the Covid-19 Pandemic
_source.title: American Indian Authorities, Trust, and Collective Action during the Covid-19 Pandemic

_source.description: We aim to identify whether women politicians have to work harder in office to be evaluated the same as men. To test this question, we have designed a conjoint experiment where we will present voters with paired profiles that describe the performance of MPs at the end of their first parliamentary term. We will assess whether there is gender bias in how voters perceive the productivity and achievements of politicians.
_source.title: Working Hard or Hardly Working? Gender and Voter Evaluations of Legislator Productivity

_source.description: We examine changes in automation risk and workers’ attitudes towards it using a two-wave panel survey (first wave administered in 2018). This study is one of few recent assessments of such over time changes. In addition, we include new questions about more recent developments, such as the effects of the pandemic, the rise of telecommuting and the AI revolution.
_source.title: Attitudes towards automation: a panel study during the COVID era

_source.description: In contexts where corrective information is scarce and party loyalties are weak, voters are more likely to punish politicians who use misinformation as part of their campaign strategy when faced with clear and targeted corrective information. I test my theory using an online survey experiment in the context of the Peruvian Presidential elections of 2021, where candidates have employed misinformation about COVID-19 treatment options and vaccines as part of their campaign strategy.
_source.title: Assessing the Effectiveness of Correcting COVID-19 Political Misinformation in Peru

_source.description: Do Endorsements by Traditional Leaders Affect Voter Attitudes? Pre-Analysis Plan
_source.title: Do Endorsements by Traditional Leaders Affect Voter Attitudes? Pre-Analysis Plan

_source.description: This survey aims to answer two separate and largely unrelated questions. First, does the disproportionate representation of certain groups in civil service employment lead to heightened resentment towards such groups, particularly on the part of members of the mass public hailing from the comparatively excluded groups? Second, what is the demand for public sector employment, measured in terms of forgone private sector employment?
_source.title: The Attitudinal Effects of Bureaucratic Under- and Over-Representation in Indonesia

_source.description: This study will investigate the role of party polarization in multi-party systems on two key aspects of representative democracies: political mobilization, i.e. turnout and political participation, and party evaluations. In order to do so, an online survey experiment will be conducted on a representative sample of 1500 French citizens.
_source.title: Party Polarization and Citizens’ Political (De)mobilization in Multi-party Systems

_source.description: Brief description of study – 2-3 sentences (the Study assess the role of African Union Election Observation Mission (AUEOM) on transparency and credibility of 2015 and 2019 General election in Nigeria. In achieving the research objective, the study seeks to answer the following question; and Trust Building Mechanisms in Nigeria? And Does the African Unions Election Observation Mission contribute to transparent and credible elections during the conduct of 2015 General election in Nigeria?)
_source.title: African Union (AU) Election Observation and Credible Election in Africa: Nigeria Experience

_source.description: The goal of this research is to combine two survey experiment techniques (list experiment and randomized rhetoric treatment) to accurately estimate actual support for political violence and analyse the effect of elite rhetoric on support for political violence.
_source.title: Pre-analysis plan for study on the level of support for, and causes of, political violence

_source.description: Dispute Resolution in Heterogeneous Societies
_source.title: Dispute Resolution in Heterogeneous Societies

_source.description: We employ a three-wave panel to investigate whether the contact between strong partisans (i.e., party delegates) in polling stations during the election day affects affective polarization. We posit that sustained contact should reduce affective polarization towards equal status members of the least liked party (rank-and-file members and, to a lesser extent, voters), whereas no impact should be observed for the opposed party’s leaders and the opposed party more generally. The effect should vary based on various mechanisms (e.g., the strength of partisan social identity; the competitiveness of the election at the precinct level; past experience in observing elections as a party delegate; the intensity and the type of the interaction; previous contact with out-party members/supporters) and may decay over time.
_source.title: Affective polarization and elections. How do (strong) partisans react?

_source.description: The novel coronavirus pandemic has increased the citizen demand for and elite supply of information on what policy measures that foreign governments had adopted and whether they have been successful in containing its spread. We aim to estimate the causal effect of information on foreign government actions on American public support for two political divisive measures: mandatory contact tracing and keeping businesses open, with the nationally representative sample of the U.S. respondents via the Cooperative Congressional Election Studies (CCES).
_source.title: Foreign News and Public Opinion on Global Pandemic Control Measures

_source.description: In this paper I use an information provision experiment conducted about a vote on Nevada’s Renewable Portfolio Standard (RPS) to understand how voter beliefs inform support f or price versus performance-based policies. By modeling how voter’s perception of policy attributes (cost, effectiveness, and equity) map to voting behavior, I will be able to decompose differences in policy support into mutable misperceptions of policy attributes versus differential aversion to certain policies (i.e., a general distaste for tax-based policy). These results have important implications for designing politically feasible corrective policies.
_source.title: What drives support for inefficient corrective policies? Evidence from an energy ballot initiative

_source.description: In contexts of corruption, voters who engage in ideological or policy voting should still continue to consider these factors along with allegations of corruption among elites, and these factors may influence their willingness to punish incumbents for corruption at the ballot box. How does a voter’s ideological distance from opposition parties affect their likelihood of engaging in corruption voting against the incumbent? We test this with a survey experiment in Mexico where both ideological and corruption voting are common influences on vote choice.
_source.title: Corruption, Ideology, and Voting: An Experiment in Mexico

_source.title: Is Indivisible Territory Indivisible (And Does It Matter)?

_source.description: The spread of Covid-19 across the globe has been accompanied by a parallel plague—that of discrimination, hostility, and violence towards minorities and immigrants—an unfortunately familiar pattern in the history of disease. We pose an empirically urgent, normatively salient question: How might we mitigate against the scapegoating of, and even encourage pro-social behavior towards, ethnic minorities on the part of majority ethnic groups in the context of the ongoing pandemic? We use a survey experiment to explore a relatively underemphasized factor—an inclusive nationalism. The dominant association of nationalism is with divisions, discrimination, and conflict. Yet nationalism has also been shown to be a powerful constructive force. The key question is how inclusively the boundaries of the nation are drawn. Drawing together and building on work across political science, sociology, economics, political theory, and social psychology, we study how a superordinate national solidarity that encompasses different ethnic groups can be leveraged to reduce the scapegoating of, and might even encourage prosocial behavior towards, minorities in the context of the Covid-19 pandemic. We study these questions in India—a country characterized by competing inclusive, secular versus exclusive, Hindu nationalist definitions of the nation which has witnessed widespread ethnic scapegoating of Muslim minorities during the Covid-19 pandemic.)
_source.title: Nationalism and Scapegoating Minorities during the COVID-19 Pandemic in India

_source.description: Anderson (1991) and other historians have argued that maps of the homeland help foster national identity. We test this central claims and explore the mechanisms whereby maps prime group identity and bring into focus a group norm to sacrifice for the defense of the homeland.
_source.title: Maps to Die For?

_source.description: This project examines whether differences in terminology impact Americans’ understanding of racism. We examine whether Americans are more willing to label racial inequities racial injustice or racial insensitivity, rather than labeling these instances racism.
_source.title: What Counts as Racism? How Conceptual Disagreement Fuels Social and Political Division

_source.description: This project examines whether party cues impact Americans’ understanding of institutional racism. We examine how party cues impact whether partisans label examples of racial disparities as racist.
_source.title: How Party Cues Shape Americans’ Understanding of Institutional Racism

_source.description: Religious rhetoric has been studied as an appeal to group identity and a signal of candidate identity but not as a factor of the credibility of candidates’ promises to voters. Some studies of violent insurgents suggest that religious ideologies are able to recruit participants by making more credible promises than secular organizations, but this study looks for an effect on the credibility of promises in conventional, nonviolent electoral campaigns. To test this, survey respondents will be randomly assigned to one of four conditions of viewing a hypothetical campaign advertisement, which will vary on whether or not the candidate justifies a position with religious rhetoric or without this rhetoric and whether or not the issue is moralized by being framed as high stakes or low stakes.
_source.title: Mechanisms of Religious Rhetoric and Political Mobilization

_source.title: Party Cues and Common European Debt: A Survey Experiment

_source.description: The influence of state capacity on citizen perceptions of distribution and, consequently their preferences and behavior has received relatively little attention in political science and economics. To address this gap in our understanding, we undertake a survey experiment in which we randomly encourage different perceptions of the state's fiscal capacity. Specifically, we ask how changes in taxpayers' perceptions of the state's fiscal capacity -- and implied distributional consequences for enforcement -- change preferences over taxation.
_source.title: Fiscal Capacity, Preferences over Taxation, and Distributional Consequences

_source.description: The study seeks to understand the effects of status signaling on domestic audiences, i.e. their perceptions of diversion/legitimacy, nationalism, policy preferences, emotions, and attitudes. It does so through an online survey experiment with Chinese respondents carrying out experimental treatments with vignettes priming Chinese respondents to think about China’s human spaceflight program and increasing international status.
_source.title: Heavenly Mandate: Evidence on Status and Legitimacy in China
