_source.description: Are diplomatic overtures less effective if they are perceived as insincerely motivated? This study examines how diplomatic donations from Russia affect American attitudes on current issues in U.S.-Russia relations. Specifically, we vary whether donations are framed as insincerely motivated, and measure how these donations influence American views on (1) U.S. sanctions against Russia and (2) the likelihood of Russia interfering in the 2020 presidential election.
_source.justification: withdrawn by EGAP staff due to transcription error in initial processing
_source.title: National Images and Foreign Policy Attitudes: Can Russia Sway American Public Opinion?

_source.description: How do race- and gender-based frames affect support for multiracial candidates and political attitudes? This study examines this question within the context of Kamala Harris’s nomination as the Democratic vice-presidential candidate in the 2020 general election. We randomly vary whether we describe Harris as a “woman,” a “Black woman,” an “Asian woman,” a “Black and Asian woman,” or omit any mention of race and gender, in a brief adapted news item about her nomination. We then measure (1) respondents’ attitudes regarding Harris’s nomination, (2) their support for Donald Trump, (3) their view on whether Harris would be prepared to become president if it became necessary during Biden’s presidency, and (4) their perception of the effect of Harris’s nomination on racial justice in the United States.
_source.title: How do race- and gender-based frames affect support for multiracial candidates and political attitudes?

_source.description: Populism Mitigation Strategies: A Survey Experiment to Decrease Populism
_source.title: Populism Mitigation Strategies: A Survey Experiment to Decrease Populism

_source.description: Public support is critical for the development and protection of judicial power—courts’ ability to exercise independence and achieve compliance with their rulings (e.g. Staton 2009). This study uses a survey experiment to test a theory about how and why co-partisanship with the President impacts citizen support for the U.S. Supreme Court’s judicial power.
_source.title: Partisanship and Citizen Support for Judicial Power in the United States

_source.description: This study aims to resolve the debate about the public perception of cyber-terrorism by running a multi-country survey experiment that will reveal the different factors that contribute to the public categorization of cyber-terrorism. Using a ratings-based conjoint methodology, we will be running a survey experiment in three countries – Israel, the United States and England - in order to identify whether the factors contributing to public classification of cyber incidents as terrorism are international or locally based. Each country will have 1,000 respondents who classify seven conjoint scenarios.
_source.title: How the Public Views Cyber-Terrorism

_source.description: This is an online survey experiment, which studies how different frames and the endorsement of political leaders shape public support for aid to other countries among Chinese nationals. The experiment looks at the support for two types of aid, one is medical and humanitarian aid to fight COVID-19, and the other is development aid in general. The treatments are different frames in favor of aid and Xi Jinping’s endorsement of aid.
_source.title: Public Support for Foreign Aid among Chinese Nationals Amidst COVID-19

_source.description: The military is held in high regard by the American public, the highest of any governmental institution, and this has remained true for several decades. It is less well-understood why the public has high confidence, and how other enduring attitudes such as partisanship, might shape public views of the military. Nor is it well-understood whether that high-level of expressed support shapes or interacts with other attitudes of interest.
_source.title: Thanks for Your Service: The Causes and Consequences of Public Confidence in the U.S. Military

_source.description: This study investigates whether conversation between Republications and Democrats can improve their affect towards opposing party members and their use of negative trait stereotypes to describe opposing party members. This study also assesses how the consequences of conversations that delve into political topics differ from those that do not.
_source.title: Interparty Conversation, Study 2

_source.description: In this study we first develop a measure of implicit ambivalent sexism. We then test how explicit and implicit ambivalent sexism relate to perceived candidate electability wherein participants are randomly assigned to different political candidates varied by gender and race.
_source.title: Understanding Electability: Implicit Bias and Its Effects on Gendered Candidate Perceptions

_source.description: This study will leverage a large survey experiment to understand drivers of risk mitigation behaviors at a large water utility in California. Specifically, we test whether particular messaging interventions, such as highlighting the gains or losses associated with disaster preparation at the organizational or individual level, increase individuals’ self-reported willingness to engage in those preparation activities.
_source.title: How Bureaucracies Address “Public Bads”: Hierarchies, Silos, and Risk Prioritization in Public Infrastructure Agencies

_source.description: Virtually no contemporary audit examining bias based on sexual orientation has been conducted in political science. Especially at a time where this minority group continues to face discrimination in credit, public accommodations, employment, and other arenas, it is essential to uncover systematic patterns of discrimination by elected officials. This plan provides an outline of the hypotheses and methodological approach that will be used in an experimental audit of state legislators to be conducted in October 2020.
_source.title: The Responsiveness of State Legislators to Lesbian and Gay Constituent Service Requests

_source.description: Our study seeks to examine if an arts-based Verbatim Performance Lab (VPL) intervention, in which viewers watch a verbatim performance of a political debate where candidates are portrayed by actors of a different gender, has an effect on viewers’ attitudes towards political leaders and broader political polarization.
_source.title: Can arts change political perceptions?

_source.description: This project looks at whether groups in American society emotionally cope with discrimination differently. We examine the issue of employment discrimination and consider differences between men and women and blacks and whites.
_source.title: Group Status and Emotionally Coping with Discrimination

_source.description: This project studies how interactive settings affect the way the public express friendly or hostile sentiment toward another country.
_source.title: Social Distance and the Expression of Anti-Foreign Sentiment: A parallel survey experiment among the American and Chinese public

_source.description: We test the effects of media portrayals of banks on people’s attitudes toward banks, financial regulation, political elites, and other related sociopolitical issues. We conduct survey experiments in six countries—Australia, France, Germany, Switzerland, the United Kingdom, and the United States.
_source.title: Banklash: The Effects of Media Portrayals of Banks

_source.description: This project explores whether and how conflict undermines preferences for female political leaders in conflict environments. We examine these processes in Afghanistan. Our identification strategy consists of randomly priming some Afghan survey respondents with information about deepening insecurity in Afghanistan. It then asks all respondents to complete a conjoint exercise of leadership profiles.
_source.title: Does Conflict Undermine Female Political Leadership? Experimental Evidence from Afghanistan

_source.description: This study examines the role of emotion, in particular anger and anxiety, in driving support for populist candidates and policies in the United States. Using two survey experiments, I will first measure whether or not populist messaging--in the form of artificial populist campaign ads--are capable of causing changes in emotional state among respondents. In the second study, I will measure whether changes in emotional state cause individuals to display higher levels of support for populism, nativism, and authoritarianism through the use of behavioral scales.
_source.title: Angry Politics: The Role of Emotion and Identity in Driving Populist Attitudes and Behavior in the United States

_source.description: Evaluating Fact-Checks During the 2020 General Election
_source.title: Evaluating Fact-Checks During the 2020 General Election
Leadership Selection Process: Consequences for Legitimacy and Efficacy Evaluations
What has the impact of the COVID-19 crisis on economic perceptions and policy preferences been?
Ethnic Representational Priorities and Citizen Action

_source.description: The study aims to contribute to the existing experimental literature on FOIA compliance and concordance. The study proposes an experiment targeted at Italian municipalities. Such an experiment aims to check whether in case of a simple request of information by one citizen: 1) municipalities’ response rate is higher, and the responses are faster if the request includes a specific reference to FOIA law; 2) municipalities’ response rate is higher, and the responses are faster if the request includes a specific reference to the title of the requester (e.g., Avv - lawyer).
_source.title: The Freedom of Information Law at Work: a field experiment in Italy
Experimental Component of Summer Bridge Program Evaluation

_source.description: In previous work, I show that low trust voters are less likely to support candidates endorsed by party leaders in congressional primaries. This study uses a survey experiment to assess the effect of endorsements from outside groups on voter support for congressional primary candidates.
_source.title: Which Cues Matter? Group Endorsements and Congressional Candidate Evaluations

_source.description: How can transnational human rights organizations (THROs) mobilize support for the Global South? Recent studies of THROs provide a rigorous, scientific understanding of the efficacy of various types of framing techniques adopted by advocacy groups. However, most of these study developed countries context, and few have investigated how these techniques impact the developing countries where serious forms of human rights violations often take place. In this study, we focus on the question of extrajudicial killings in the Philippines. We test three framing techniques, namely, personal, informational, and motivational frames, as tested in the US context by McEntire et al. (2015). In addition, we test the effects of the justice frame drawn from the social movement literature and ongoing practices in the Philippines on the support for human rights.
_source.title: Transnational Human Rights Advocacy and Domestic Responses in the Global South: Evidence from the Philippines

_source.description: An old adage holds that “only Nixon could go to China.” In other words, hawkish leaders face lower domestic barriers to pursuing conciliation with foreign enemies than dovish leaders. Is it similarly more difficult for female leaders to pursue peace than male leaders? We argue that female leaders do indeed face greater domestic barriers to pursuing peace.
_source.title: Could a Woman Have Gone to China? Evidence of a Gendered Peace Premium

_source.description: The study is a survey experiment collected over the phone to assess the extent to which individual characteristics affect the perceived electoral viability of a candidate. Specifically, we randomize information about the gender, race, sexual orientation, and political capital of a hypothetical candidate and ask a representative national sample of Brazilian respondents about the candidate’s probability of being elected, and whether they would vote for that candidate.
_source.title: More representation: Voters’ preferences and candidate electoral viability

_source.description: We conduct a vignette survey experiment to detect bias against ethnic minority candidates among Norwegian politicians. In addition, we conduct a list experiment among Norwegian voters to examine bias against voting for a party list with ethnic minority candidates.
_source.title: Are Politicians Biased Against Ethnic Minority Candidates? Evidence from Norwegian Survey Experiments

_source.description: This study will investigate how infection incidence, governments’ economic relief plan, and democratic procedures affects citizens’ opinions on the governments’ performance, social cohesion and their willingness to comply with Covid-19 prevention measures. Based on a full-factorial survey experiment implemented in 11 countries across Europe, we facilitate internal as well as external validity supporting causal claims.
_source.title: Severity, economic relief or transparency? Experimental evidence on support of and compliance with Covid-19 prevention measures across Europe

_source.description: The goal of this project is to compare the impact of different types of gender representation on women’s political engagement: by considering women’s collective representation, dyadic representation, and issue representation in our experimental framework, we aim to better understand the mechanisms connecting representation and engagement.
_source.title: Representation and Political Engagement

_source.description: We will conduct a nation-wide field experiment in Danish high schools, investigating the effect of providing them with skills (tips to spot fake news) and motivation (a peer feedback instruction) on their ability to correctly assess the veracity of news headlines.
_source.title: Raising digital awareness among digital natives: Evidence from a nation-wide field experiment on fake news discernment in Danish high schools

_source.description: In this study we examine the relationship between emotions, specifically anxiety, and information seeking in the context of COVID 19. Using cross-sectional survey data and measures of reported and observed information seeking behavior, we investigate the link between anxiety and information seeking about COVID 19, focusing on the quantity and the nature of the information relative to existing media and political preferences.
_source.title: Information, Anxiety and COVID 19 – Evidence from Russia

_source.description: Exit and Voice in Hong Kong
_source.title: Exit and Voice in Hong Kong
How Parental Leave Policies Shape Beliefs toward Gender Equality
Elections And The Time Horizons of Politicians: A Three-Year Panel Experiment with Local Elected Representatives

_source.description: Electoral violence of different types likely shapes these contests as well as other outcomes such as trust in the state. However, policymakers remain constrained in their ability to transform research insights into actionable policy interventions aimed at either reducing the incidence of violence or mitigating its effects on citizens. A major obstacle is the lack of appropriate data showing where different types of electoral violence occurs. In this project, we embed an experiment into a citizen survey with vignettes that vary the type of violence, identity of the perpetrator, the number of perpetrators, the identity of the victim, and the number of witnesses involved in hypothetical incidents of violence. The goal is to better understand under what conditions citizens will be willing to report violence as well as the underlying motivation to do so.
_source.title: Documenting Electoral Violence: Assessing Tradeoffs in Data Collection Methodologies

_source.description: The AmeRicans’ Conceptions of Health Equity Study (ARCHES) is an interdisciplinary, two-phase investigation of how Americans form and change their views about who deserves what in the health realm. Phase I involves (a) ethnographic observation of a multisectoral health equity initiative, and (b) 170 semistructured interviews with a diverse range of community leaders, health professionals, and residents in Greater Cleveland, Ohio, including those exposed and unexposed to the health equity initiative. Participant observation and interviews aim to generate a deeper understanding of underlying sentiments that shape public opinion on health policy. In Phase II, this grounded understanding of what shapes Americans’ conceptions of health-related deservingness is tested in a nationally representative online survey. This is an omnibus pre-registration for the three experiments included in the survey.
_source.title: The AmeRicans’ Conceptions of Health Equity Study | ARCHES

_source.description: This study is meant to measure the baseline level of support amongst citizens for the provision of resources (staff, compensation, etc.) to legislators/legislatures and assess the effect of new information on these levels of support. A pre-post experimental design will assess the effect of information revealing that highly resourced legislatures provide 1) positive returns to social welfare and 2) more congruent policy outcomes on voters’ preferences for resource support.
_source.title: Voter support for legislative resources

_source.description: We seek to implement a survey experiment exploring the effect of a foreign source of authority on the preferences of citizens over economic austerity. We have a general hypothesis about framing: people do not like external influence.
_source.title: The Effect of Foreign Authority on Preferences for Austerity

_source.description: Career decisions and gender bias within households
_source.title: Career decisions and gender bias within households

_source.description: Gender-bias in promotion
_source.title: Gender-bias in promotion

_source.description: Through a randomized control trial we evaluate a recently introduced debt-installment policy by the public electricity company UTE in Uruguay on reducing electricity informality. We send information treatments in the form of letters to non-poor households who accumulated debt during 2020. We test the effect of a policy reminder designed to raise awareness of the policy, combined with horizontal and vertical reciprocity treatments, on the likelihood that households remain formal consumers. We analyze the effect of different treatment arms using administrative data on individual payment behavior and original survey data, thus analyzing behavioral and attitudinal changes.
_source.title: Delaying Enforcement Amid Crisis: The compliance effects of communicating state flexibility in the residential electricity sector.

_source.description: This document is a pre-analysis plan for observational study based on a three-wave panel of Afghan respondents regarding attitudes towards peace negotiations. We specify two primary approaches: (1) a descriptive exercise that analyzes the cross-sectional predictors of peace attitudes and predictors of changes over time within individuals. We will characterize how stable attitudes are towards peace. (2) an analytic exercise that estimates the causal effect of different types of violence, as well as territorial control, on short and medium run attitudes towards peace. At the time of writing, we have access only to baseline (wave 1) survey data, and will only access the outcome data after the design has been formally registered.
_source.title: How do violence and territorial control impact civilian preferences for negotiated peace?

_source.description: How do gendered networks in Congress impact the process and outcomes of legislating? We theorize that while women member of Congress still face a number of barriers within the legislative body, including less prestigious committee appointments, growing numbers and increased institutional support in recent years has allowed them to establish stronger gendered networks that allow them to increase their efficacy and legislative outcomes. This theory will be tested with a novel dataset of survey and interview data with current members of Congress and their staff members.
_source.title: The Legislative and Practical Implications of Gendered Networks in Congress

_source.description: Do Endorsements by Traditional Leaders Affect Voter Attitudes? Pre-Analysis Plan
_source.justification: Force withdrawn by moderator: withdrawn due to typo in the title during upload by EGAP staff
_source.title: Do Endorsements by Traditional Leaders Affect Voter Attitudes? Pre-Analysis Plan

_source.description: Survey experiment to test causal effects of protester cohesion on protest concessions. Complements prior observational study.
_source.title: Crowd Cohesion and Protest Outcomes

_source.description: Women's exposure to GBV and IPV may be especially acute amid COVID-19, which has led to a notable increase in reported violence, particularly in the Global South. Building on recent studies on the role of edutainment and community-level interventions in combatting GBV and IPV, we partnered with an Egyptian women’s rights non-governmental organization to examine an intervention delivered amid COVID-19 via traditional and social media that are widely used in the Egyptian context. We measure the degree to which the intervention shifts attitudes toward GBV and IPV, knowledge about resources, and behaviors in response.
_source.title: Violence Against Women amid COVID-19: The Effects of Social and Traditional Media Campaigns to Empower Women

_source.description: This study will conduct a three-arm randomized controlled trial (RCT) to understand COVID-19 vaccine uptake among individuals in Lahore, Pakistan.
_source.title: Public trust and the politics of Pakistan’s COVID-19 vaccination program

_source.description: We will test for differences in intention to be vaccinated for COVID-19 in the United States after receiving messages under two different (positive) frames. One frame varies whether the message emphasized the effect on the individual versus the effect on the public/others. The second variation randomizes whether the message is about health versus individual freedoms/economic activity. Finally, for each of these four combinations of possible messages, the messenger will vary between two partisan figures and one public health figure.
_source.title: Is it the message, the messenger or both? The Politics of COVID-19 vaccination intentions

_source.description: Numerous studies have used experimental approaches to examine how voters evaluate the policy content of party manifestos. This study applies similar research designs to test the value of policy competence, or “realistic” combinations of fiscal expenditures and revenues. We design a conjoint experiment in Japan that randomly varies nine policy attributes of party manifestos and ask respondents to evaluate them for policy competence.
_source.title: How Do Voters Evaluate Policy Competence? A Conjoint Analysis

_source.description: We conduct a survey experiment to show that international media's issue framing affects citizens' support for their governments' overseas third-party interventions. If the media focuses on the details of the suppression rather than the protesters' demand, citizens will be more likely to urge their governments to take strict actions to terminate a political suppression overseas.
_source.title: Media framing effect on public support for third-party intervention strategies

_source.description: We explore how the structure of outcome questions in conjoint experiments affects the qualities of the Average Marginal Component Effect (AMCE). We do so with a replication of Mummolo (2016) which randomly assigns some respondents to make forced choices among the pairs of news stories and other respondents to either choice one news story in the pair or abstain from making a choice.
_source.title: Media Selection Replication

_source.description: Despite the efforts made to understand the effectiveness of propaganda in authoritarian countries, one question overlooked is the differential propaganda effects in various conditions under which people are exposed to these propaganda messages. Scholars long have known that media effects are heterogenous, differing by messages and individual characters. However, less attention has been paid to varying contexts. In this study, I intend to uncover propaganda effects under two conditions: forced versus selective exposure, in the case of China.
_source.title: The Effects of Forced Versus Selective Propaganda Exposure in China

_source.description: A survey experiment that aims to show how simple language in combination with a populist rhetoric affects citizens with a left or right ideological background differently. Further, it shows how respondents underlying political attitudes and personal characteristics interact with simple language.
_source.title: Simplicity of Populist Messages and Its Effect on Citizens - A Survey Experiment

_source.description: Can immigration flow type affect native prejudice? This project builds upon theories of prejudice, contact, and nation-building to theorize that immigration within economic sectors of importance to national identity reduce native prejudicial attitudes and behaviour.
_source.title: National Identity and Immigrant Attitudes in the UK

_source.description: We investigate whether political incivility and intolerance increase support for political violence, considering the moderating roles of racial resentment and localized group conflict. We will conduct a 2x2 survey experiment with a control group, manipulating both uncivil and intolerant language. We estimate neighborhood context by linking respondent zip codes with data on neighborhood-level racial heterogeneity.
_source.title: Rhetoric and Political Violence: Considering the Role of Neighborhood Context

_source.title: Viral solidarity? EU Solidarity and Risk-Sharing in the COVID-19 Crisis

_source.description: Do the Japanese people have a taboo regarding nuclear possession by their government or the use of such weapons by the United States in defense of Japan? A nuclear taboo is widely discussed and has been the object of numerous survey experiments in the United States, but it is not known if the taboo operates in countries other than the US or if the taboo extends to the acquisition rather than the employment of such weapons.
_source.title: An Empirical Assessment of Nuclear Taboo in Japan

_source.title: The Limits of Decentralized Data Collection: Experimental Evidence from Colombia

_source.title: Women Grab Back: Exclusion and Women Candidates for Office

_source.description: In this project, we propose to conduct analyses of elections and well-being in Côte d’Ivoire and Ghana. Elections, we believe, will produce different effects on well-being in these two neighboring West African countries.
_source.title: Elections and Well-Being in Africa: A Comparative Analysis of Côte d’Ivoire and Ghana

_source.description: The study conducts a conjoint survey experiment to identify how patterns of violence shape individual decisions to flee. We explore if and how individuals that have a broader social network within their own country and abroad respond differently to violence and may differ in their decisions to relocate in the context of decades of violence in Eastern and Southeastern Turkey.
_source.title: When to go? – A conjoint experiment on social networks, violence and forced migration decisions in Eastern and Southeastern Turkey

_source.description: Sounding the Alarm: Transgressing Democratic Norms and the Effects of Political Pushback
_source.title: Sounding the Alarm: Transgressing Democratic Norms and the Effects of Political Pushback

_source.description: Are diplomatic overtures less effective if they are perceived as insincerely motivated? This study examines how diplomatic donations from Russia affect American attitudes on current issues in U.S.-Russia relations. Specifically, we vary whether donations are framed as insincerely motivated, and measure how these donations influence American views on (1) U.S. sanctions against Russia and (2) the likelihood of Russia interfering in the 2020 presidential election.
_source.title: National Images and Foreign Policy Attitudes: Can Russia Sway American Public Opinion?

_source.description: Field Experiment on the Italian 2020 Referendum Campaign: Pre-roll and Autoplay Video Ads
_source.title: Field Experiment on the Italian 2020 Referendum Campaign: Pre-roll and Autoplay Video Ads

_source.description: Social cleavage theory suggests that social structure translates into politics through the mobilization of collective identities. This study focuses on exactly this translation, paying special attention to the political supply side of group formation. In the survey experiment presented here, we explore the bounded malleability of group identities in contexts of electoral realignment by priming voters to think about party politics in their country as centering on a) the (newer) universalism-particularism divide or b) the (older) state-market divide.
_source.title: Identity Formation between Structure and Agency – How ‘Us’ and ‘Them’ Relates to Voting Behavior in Contexts of Electoral Realignment

_source.description: This project aims to test an underlying assumption of recent work on the origins of programmatic social welfare policies under autocracy – that autocratic rulers have an incentive to offer policy commitments that benefit groups of individuals, rather than discretionary distribution of private goods toward individual supporters. Using observational data and randomized framing from a regionally representative survey, we test whether Saudi citizens evaluate the credibility of the regime’s commitments based on its delivery of club (i.e. group-based) goods to broad categories of citizens rather than individual benefits.
_source.title: Spatial Cleavages and Performance Legitimacy: Evidence from Saudi Arabia

_source.description: This study examines the role that the exposure to conspiracy theories through an emotive frame plays on individuals’ perceptions of the conspiracy theory. The use of negative emotive language has a powerful impact on how individuals interact with information. Further, the presence of these emotions has been observed in conspiracy theories. This study aims to determine the impact that these emotions have in the context of conspiracy theories.
_source.title: Explaining the Variation in Individuals' Conspiratorial Beliefs: The Effect of Exposure to Emotive Conspiratorial Messaging in the Media

_source.description: The impact of coronavirus on territorial politics. A comparative analysis.
_source.title: The impact of coronavirus on territorial politics. A comparative analysis.

_source.description: This is the Pre-Analysis Plan (PAP) of a proposed survey experiment designed to identify how different types of crises affect voters’ attitudes towards female candidates and candidates that comply or not with gendered stereotypes.
_source.title: Contexts of crises and voters’ behavior toward gendered candidates

_source.description: Type/tone of media discrimination, as well as the cultural masculinity a person lives under, may impact whether they respond to media discrimination by feeling motivated or demotivated, regarding their interest in entering politics and their reasons for being interested. This study will test whether women in a highly masculine culture versus a highly feminine culture react to media (that is either gender neutral, benevolently discriminatory or hostilely discriminatory) differently. Three primary theoretical paths to politics are considered, based on social and political psychology research: 1) implicit cognition path – women exposed to benevolently discriminatory media experience only implicit through processes that lead to greater system justification, role incongruity between the political and female gender roles and other factors that decrease their interest in entering politics; 2) the reactance path – women exposed to hostile media discrimination in a feminine culture feel anger based motivation to enter politics as a form of collective action on behalf of women; 3) the queen bee path – women exposed to hostile media discrimination in a masculine culture experience self-group distancing as a coping mechanism and enter politics as a way to attain self-advancement in a masculine domain. In the online experiment testing these expectations, the effect of media on other variables is tested, in order to provide some initial suggestive evidence as to the causal mechanisms that cannot be directly tested. Theoretically relevant control variables such as ideology, ethnicity and level of education are included, as these have been found to impact not only women’s political ambition but how women respond to gender discrimination.
_source.title: Under what conditions can media discrimination increase women’s political ambition?

_source.description: Project is exploiting a research design (RCT) to test innovative ways to improve the skills and competencies of the local labour force, and to boost employment and growth in the region.
_source.title: Urban growth - GSIP Vantaa

_source.description: This project uses a conjoint survey design to test which attributes affect perceptions of land values and tenure security. We consider how valuable the property is deemed to be when protected by state or traditional authorities, and, more directly, perceptions about how likely it is that the land would be taken.
_source.title: Authority and Land Titling in Malawi

_source.description: Does nationalism increase belief in misinformation? From the United States to India, analysts and public commentators increasingly assume that nationalism fuels misinformation. However, existing work in political science has neither theoretically nor empirically examined this relationship. In this study, we address this gap by studying the link between nationalism and belief in misinformation in Pakistan -- a context rife with both—through a survey experiment of 2350 respondents. We focus on the impact of nationalism on belief in misinformation along three salient issue areas: external outgroups, domestic outgroups, and the role of the nation in the international sphere.
_source.title: Does Nationalist Sentiment Increase Belief in Misinformation? Experimental Evidence from Pakistan

_source.description: The study aims to pilot two interventions designed to reduce the frequency of face touching. The study will be fielded as a survey experiment where outcomes are measured using video recordings.
_source.title: Testing Communication Strategies to Increase Compliance with COVID‐19 Policies on Public Transport

_source.description: We have designed an experiment to recover the marginal willingness to pay for neighborhood features. The primary neighborhood feature we are interested in recovering the marginal willingness to pay for is co-partisanship
_source.title: Pricing Partisanship

_source.description: This study investigates how conservative politicians and commentators/pundits/figure heads Tweet on Twitter. In particular, I will be using topic modeling and other forms of analyses to determine whether pre-Trump tweeting predicted eventual support for (or never-Trump opposition to) the president. I’ll also be looking at whether and how their Twitter feeds change in the event that he loses.
_source.title: Conservatism/Ideology Post 2020
Citizen Responses to Ethnic Representation
Gender Norm Violation and Attitudes toward Equality

_source.description: Descriptive representation is not increased through candidacies alone, but also through voters responding favorably to candidates’ platforms. This study investigates voters’ reactions to the motivations for running for office presented by women candidates in primary elections using evidence from a survey experiment.
_source.title: Enraged and Engaged: Anger in Primary Campaigns

_source.description: Brief description of study – When learning about judicial candidates running for re-election, this study looks at whether off-the-bench articles, such as stories about the justice’s lives outside of the Court, or on-the-bench articles, such as stories about the justices participating in Court activities, motivate justices to learn more about the Court. I look at voters from three states that had justices running for re-election during the November 2020 general election: Missouri, Michigan, and North Carolina.
_source.title: Interest in Judicial Candidates

_source.description: This research seeks to better understand how to promote youth voting in Vietnamese elections. We ask: what is the relationship between current election promotion approaches of the State and Party with quality voting participation from Ho Chi Minh City educated youths?
_source.justification: withdrawn due to upload error; EGAP staff to re-upload
_source.title: YOUTH CHARACTERISTICS AND MOBILIZATION APPROACHES IN THE 2021 VIETNAMESE ELECTION

_source.description: This study embeds experiments in a survey of victims and non-victims in Colombia to understand how parties guilty of violence against the civilian population seek that population’s votes and when and why a victimized population would elect its tormentors to govern it. It tests a theory, which argues that these tormentors sell themselves and, in turn, become seen as the most credible providers of social peace.
_source.title: Victims and Non-Victims in Colombia
Fragile Masculinity

_source.description: This study involves an 8-week panel survey experiment that measures how the positive or negative valence of news articles about climate change influences long-term perceptions, behaviors and policy attitudes. Participants (recruited online) will answer baseline questions about their climate change attitudes, then read a series of either positively or negatively valanced news articles about climate change over the course of four weeks. Resulting climate change attitudes will be measured at week 5, and again at week 8.
_source.title: The Impact of Message Valence on Climate Change Attitudes: A Longitudinal Study

_source.description: What factors help facilitate the re-integration of former Islamic militants into host communities? This paper looks at the interplay between the personal, economic and social attributes of ex-combatants to understand what facilitates successful reintegration of ex-combatants. In order to test our hypotheses we run a conjoint survey experiment with over 1500 Somali citizens from 75 communities spread over the three cities where DDR centers are currently running. Additionally we test our hypotheses with various sub-groups such as tribal elders, religious leaders, women leaders and youths allowing us to identify and compare different attributes within and across these groups in a single experiment.
_source.title: What Attributes Matter During Re-integration of Islamic Militants- Experimental Evidence from Somalia

_source.description: This study investigates the extent to which feelings of electoral threat condition the effectiveness of interparty contact on affective polarization. We expect that contact will be less effective at reducing outparty animosity among those who experience electoral threat (Republicans in our case, based on the results of the 2020 US presidential election), compared to those who experience electoral reassurance (Democrats in our case, based on the results of the 2020 US presidential election).
_source.title: Electoral Threat and the Impact of Interparty Contact on Affective Polarization

_source.description: This document is an outline for a analysis plan for a set of data on the 1918 Influenza Pandemic in the United States, testing both the effects of political competitiveness on flu deaths and cases, and the political repercussions of these flu-related measures. It utilizes data from the Influenza Encyclopedia at the University of Michigan, archived news articles from the Library of Congress, and 1910 Census data, CLEA congressional election data from 1916, 1918, and 1920, data of major U.S. Army bases in WWI from the U.S. Army Center of Military History, NOAA monthly weather data, and data on public health from Project Tycho at the University of Pittsburgh. We lay out a set of competing hypotheses for a set of potential effects to test.
_source.title: Political Accountability and the 1918 Influenza Pandemic

_source.description: Driving us further apart? The impact of social media news exposure on attitudes toward Covid-19 policies
_source.title: Driving us further apart? The impact of social media news exposure on attitudes toward Covid-19 policies

_source.description: We test how the policy positions of in- and out-party leaders affect the policy positions of American partisans. We have already conducted two experiments using convenience samples, and we have found that partisans update their policy positions more for in-party leaders but they nevertheless respond positively to the positions of out-party leaders. We plan to replicate these findings on a nationally representative sample.
_source.title: Learning from the Opposition

_source.description: The Politics of COVID-19: Experimental Evidence of the Individual Perceptions of the Pandemic
_source.title: The Politics of COVID-19: Experimental Evidence of the Individual Perceptions of the Pandemic

_source.description: The goal of this project is to compare the impact of different types of gender representation on women’s political engagement: by considering women’s collective representation, dyadic representation, and issue representation in our experimental framework, we aim to better understand the mechanisms connecting representation and engagement.
_source.title: Representation and Political Engagement

_source.description: Preferences for the use and regulation of algorithms in the context of self-driving cars and algorithmic decision-making
_source.title: Preferences for the use and regulation of algorithms in the context of self-driving cars and algorithmic decision-making

_source.description: (PILOT STUDY) How does repression influence democratic candidates’ vote share? In this conjoint experiment, I test the relationship between candidates’ support for repressive policies and their electoral performance in the context of the 2020 U.S. elections. I expect that candidates who support repression against groups perceived as threatening will increase their vote share compared to candidates who do not support repression.
_source.title: Why Voters (Sometimes) Reward Repression in Democracies

_source.description: This registration describes analysis procedures for additional outcome measures that have been obtained for the same field experiment that has been described in the previous registrations that fall under this project (EGAP Registration ID 20181105AA). The new outcome measurements consist of geo-located administrative crime data that have been obtained through an official request for information from the South African Police Service (SAPS).
_source.title: Encouraging Cooperation with the State - A Field Experiment on Household Connections to the Police - Administrative Data Collection

_source.description: We will test for whether partisanship affects perceptions of risk to self and risk to the population for COVID-19 infections, three different characterizations of terrorist attacks, and floods.
_source.title: Partisanship, Risk Assessment and Optimism Bias

_source.description: Previous observational studies evaluating the role of racial attitudes in evaluations of African American candidates and gender attitudes in evaluations of women candidates rely on a “comparison” approach in which an African American (or female) candidate is compared to a white (or male) candidate who is similar in some important respects. This approach leaves open the possibility that differences in the relative importance of racial and gender attitudes on the evaluation of candidates are due to extraneous factors that are unrelated to the candidates’ racial and/or gender identities. Experimental studies can more confidently isolate the causal effects of racial and gender cues, but are limited by external validity concerns due to their usual reliance on fictional candidates. The experimental design proposed here aims to address these concerns by holding a real-world candidate – Kamala Harris – constant and varying the salience of her race or gender.
_source.title: An Experimental Test of the Effects of Racial and Gender Cues on Support for Kamala Harris

_source.description: I show a sample of Latinx registered voters political messaging from a partisan political campaign that jointly varies in its racial and economic content. I test whether these messages have heterogeneous effects among individuals as a function of their partisanship and Latinx group consciousness.
_source.title: How Latinx Diversity Affects Responses to Partisan Campaign Appeals

_source.description: An experiment to test whether standard question formats exaggerate voters’ support for federal spending.
_source.title: Fiscal Attitudes, Experiment 1

_source.description: We conduct a conjoint experiment with federal lobbyists to determine which characteristics they “value” most in lobbyists. This study with contribute to ongoing dialogues in research on Congress, organized interests, and “revolving door” lobbying.
_source.title: Lobbyist Hiring Experiment
